name: Command & Conquer 3: Tiberium Wars
description: The year is 2047. A massive nuclear fireball explodes high in the night sky, marking the dramatic beginning of the Third Tiberium War and the long-awaited return of the most groundbreaking Real-Time Strategy franchise of all time.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP/Vista Processor: 2GHz AMD Athlon™ processor or equivalent Memory: 512MB RAM  Graphics: ATI Radeon 8500 or Nvidia GeForce 4 or higher video card Hard Drive: 8GB Sound: DirectX 9.0c-compatible sound card Other Requirements: Internet service required to access online features, Broadband modem required for 3 to 8 players and voice support INTERNET CONNECTION, ONLINE AUTHENTICATION AND ACCEPTANCE OF END USER LICENSE AGREEMENT REQUIRED TO PLAY. TO ACCESS ONLINE FEATURES, YOU MUST REGISTER ONLINE. ONLY ONE REGISTRATION IS AVAILABLE PER GAME. EA ONLINE TERMS & CONDITIONS AND FEATURE UPDATES CAN BE FOUND AT <a href="https://steamcommunity.com/linkfilter/?url=http://WWW.EA.COM" target="_blank" rel="noopener"  >WWW.EA.COM. YOU MUST BE 13+ TO REGISTER WITH EA ONLINE. EA MAY RETIRE ONLINE FEATURES AFTER 30 DAYS NOTICE POSTED ON <a href="https://steamcommunity.com/linkfilter/?url=http://WWW.EA.COM" target="_blank" rel="noopener"  >WWW.EA.COM.

reviews.review_text: Game works perfectly on Windows 8  Graphics still hold up to this day  There is no unit limit  Game is balanced  Music is great  Campaign is pretty long. Possible to play as all 3 sides.  Not sure about in-game multiplayer services, but hamachi/Gameranger work fine.  AI can put up a fight and has different 'characters' (Agressive, defensive, etc).
Probably the last good C&C game with it's Kane's wrath expansion

Ignore my hours. I had this game on disk since it first came out, and honestly, its had more time put into it than any of my other strategy games put together.  When Westwood still existed the C&C series always were wonderful to play - There was just that touch of polish and care which went into their games that you didn't quite get with others, even right down to the little animations of the commandos lighting a cigerrette and chucking it aside, quoting one of their infamous lines with a chuckle. So for 2D units you were commanding quite a colourful and unique army.  However when C&C3 came along... Oohh boy, that jump into 3D. It brought fresh life to the series! ... too bad it was the last 'good' game beyond Red Alert 3 after that. EA had washed everything 'Westwood' down the drain.   As always the three factions are almost brilliantly balanced; They each have strengths and flaws which play a triangular role against one another, with similar but unique powers and tech trees. While they can be infamous for certain reasons - Scrin with their hordes of alien ships for example - there is no reason why a player cannot use either GDI or NOD to the same extent and counter it.   From the previous two games the missions are also once again varied, can last you a while, and the AI can be dubious when you're unprepared (if not a little clumsy here or there) which means you can get quite a few hours out of Skirmish mode.  -- Edit -- Unfortunately however these days the game's multiplayer has all but dissolved. I think there is still a small community and you might still be able to play matches, though its rare and you're going to have to go out and find it. Despite this I still enjoy playing the game and its Kanes Wrath expansion as a time waster and fond memory of the good times I had with it. --  Like I said. Sad to see its the last 'good' game of the series. Command & Conquer 4 'Twilight' ruined the finale to the story by ripping out the core gameplay mechanics, making maps capture-the-flag esque and point control, while plummeting the player into a final 'thats all folks!' with the ending. If you want a true C&C game, get Tiberum Dawn or Sun. If you want an enjoyable 3d C&C game, get this, or Red Alert 3.

This is one of my personal favourites as their is a great selection of special abilities each faction has which if you use correctly, will change the tides of the battle. I hate the fact that wall construction was removed, spotlights back at Tiberium sun and other majestic buildings in firestorm/ Tiberium sun. Still ♥♥♥♥ you EA For the ♥♥♥♥ sexual and ending to the Tiberium franchise that we all know and hate, except for that one kid in this current generation that says 'Better then the previous titles, probably more better than Generals' If you ever encounter that kid, punch him in the nuts and say, ♥♥♥♥ you. I enjoyed the game, bought it 5 times with dlc for friends cause there is a way to revive the multiplayer use a site called Revora C&C and download the online multiplayer hooking tool thing that launches with your game, after you click the play button on steam press the game you selected and play, you will require an account from their site. And there is a tool called Gentool which I think Should revive multiplayer for generals.
I loved Red Alert when it came out, I bought this and it seems pretty close to it so far. Standard EA closing servers. I love that company, they are so great for gaming.
Sadly I can't play this on my Windows 10 but otherwise its a good game

Command and Conquer is a legendary franchise that is much beloved by people all over the world. A franchise that unfortunately has remained dormant for some time and most likely will continue to do so. But most of the games contained within it are extremely great, and this one is no exception.  C&C 3 takes place in the Tiberium Wars arc that began with the original game. The world has prospered under the control of the GDI. A sort of United Nations military force, that combats terror threats. However, a quasi-religious cult known as the Brotherhood of Nod reappears to try and take control by force. The thing I like the most about Command and Conquer is it feels the closest to present day warfare compared to other RTS games such as Starcraft. It features a very well funded military symbolizing 'peace' and 'order' against an anarchistic anti authoritarian movement. And the entire conflict revolves around the accumulation of a resource known as Tiberium.  This also ties into the general gameplay of the series and this game in particular. In Command and Conquer there aren't any worker units and buildings are queued similar to units. Your units tend to be squads of footsoldiers, tanks, jet fighters and so forth. Even though it is a very sci-fi game with aliens, lazer beams and so forth. It still feels much more down to earth. Infantry units die very quickly to units carrying rifles, but are useless against buildings and vehicles. Wheras vehicles have lots of health and can carry other units but are weak against explosives. It's a game where you have to pay very close attention to what units you're controlling and which ones are attacking which.   C&C 3 in particular takes a few cues from other RTS games like Starcraft. It adds an alien race known as the 'Scrin'. Who have their own unlockable campaign. Although there are very few surprises when playing as the Scrin, they queue their units the same and their buildings are mostly similar. But there are statistical differences to playing it. Which unfortunately only become really prominent at higher levels of play.   My favorite aspect of C&C 3 in particular is it's skirmish mode. Specifically how customizeable it is. You can set a particular AI opponent to have different mannerisms. Like you can set an AI opponent to turtle, meaning staying in his base and preferring to not attack. Or you can set an AI opponent to be a rusher, who will attack at the soonest moment. It's one of my favorite RTS games to play exclusively in singleplayer for this reason. Multiplayer is also available however you will need to use third party methods to get connected as it ran on Gamespy which has been shut down.  Solid RTS, one of my favorites. Easily recommended if you're a fan of campaign and skirmish.

This game has no life without the Tibeium Essence mod. If you own the game currently, seriously, get this mod.   The game on it's own is a fantastic game, with major potential.  I think my favourite strategy would be using raider buggies with camo, then making them EMP other units, before then releasing the avatars on the EMP'd vehicles.  Campaign is bland as usual, don't expect anything merely 'Good' there. 3/10  I would rate it a 10/10 with tiberium essence, and a 6/10 without it. Simply, the game has amazing potential, and Tiberium Essence really brings it to life.

Tons of fun, The matches usually finish after about 25 mins, so if your looking for a slower, more defensive RTS this isn't the game for you. Other than that it is quick, permenant action with a lot of replay value.

When I bought this game, I expected fast pace intense gameplay, and that's what I got. The campaign is long and challenging, which is good, excluding the Scrin campaign which was only 4 missions. While playing through the campaign you are presented with HD cinematics (before, after and during missions) which are fairly cheesy and unconvincing, however, it's better then nothing. The graphics, although not perfect, are very nice. Bottom line, if you have ever liked any C&C game, or you like RTS games in general, then I highly suggest you buy this because your missing out on a good game.

You can still play it with a friend/s with Hamachi, just make sure the friend will ACTUALY play with you. Unlike mine, who plays 1 a day before he goes to play Counter Strike GO. Quote from him: CNC is my childhood Me: Yea, revisiting your childhood my ♥♥♥. 1 or 2 games a day? Such a long visit back into your childhood.

I've been playing CnC since the original 1995 release and I was heartbroken by the death of the original Westwood Studios. EA managed one good release CnC: Generals and its expansion, which will never supass my love of the orignal Red Alert but may be the finest multiplayer experience I've ever had, in the ranks of Starcraft and Total Annihilation.  That said, CnC3 and RA3 had been almost intolerable. The graphics, the gameplay, everything seems to be downgrade of what they've already done and the very well produced FMV's aren't enough to overcome that you're playing the same game that was much better the last time they made it.
Nostalgie aside: Played the heck out of this game almost 10 years ago, maybe i just grew to old or bored with rts but didnt enjoy it

On easy, the computer enemy is wayyyyy to smart. You shouldn't get attacked from 3 different angles on easy. Online is dead. Kane's Wrath still has people that play online, but not this game.

Multiplayer is grossly unbalanced. The Scrin faction is just super OP. Aside from that, the campaign seems to be strong and I've been playing a lot of both multiplayer and single player and have enjoyed it despite all the flaws.

Having previously played Generals to death I was very excited when CNC3 came out. It delivered better graphics and better netcode (the franchise's previous game 'Generals' would crash every other time in multiuplayer) but the gameplay was a huge step backwards, with the only required tactics being to build tanks which could easily defeat defenses, infantry, air units and other tanks. There was no need to build anything else and as a result the game became very simplistic and predictable.  The AI in CNC3 was also a step backwards from Generals. It didn't attack with mixed units most of the time, and it rarely defended it's base at all. When it did it often used just one type of defense, which of course makes for an easy attack.  Out of frustration, a friend and I worked on a mod with the help of the rest of the TALON Clan. The TALON Mod made a lot of changes to the game that made it much more balanced, fun, challenging and enjoyable to play. Look for it on ModDB.

The AI gets a little wonky from time to time but other than that I have no complaints.

A great comeback for Command & Conquer! It may be different than the Westwood era, but it's a solid and VERY fun game. Great campaign, great multiplayer. Joe Kucan is back and the Brotherhood kicks moar azz than ever! It's nice to be able to play a modern C&C game with the old gameplay style :)

I originally purchased this game when it first came out years ago. My rig at the time was slightly crippled by the awesome battles, but now, armed with a somewhat high spec machine and a Dell U2711, I was worried the 1440p resolution wouldn't work. So glad I was wrong! This game looks just as good, if not better, than it did when it first came out and I have found myself falling in love with it all over again. Haven't tried multiplayer as I always sucked at it. But the campaign is great and the skirmish is fun. The battles are entertaining and the intensity, colour and light will make you want to wear sunglasses its so awesome! Now just need to get Kane's Wrath and continue to bathe in the nostalgia. GET THIS GAME!

Decent game. My only complaints are:  EA completeley changed the atmosphere of the game. It went from post-apocalyptic, dramatic and gloomy with some heavy science-fiction elements, to Modern Warfare as an RTS game with aliens. They completely got rid of a lot of aspects that made Tiberian Sun such an atmospheric game, such as map-wide ion storms, tiberium mutants (while they still exist canonically they only rarely make appearances), and NOD was dumbed down greatly in the sense that their technology now sucks pretty badly and their numbers/strength are fairly laughable.    You can't have a singleplayer skirmish without the AI spamming grenadiers/black hand/buzzers. Those are the only infantry units that the game's AI will make and it makes it extremely frustrating to employ infantry of your own because those three types of troops clear garrisons and kill infantry instantly.  The scrin are OP - it's mostly a matter of how you fight them but considering they get fighters that don't need to re-arm and gunships and frigates and all that and the NOD and GDI only have fighters and some light AA, it's not really fun to go up against them unless you know exactly what you're doing. -Another thing about the Scrin is that all or most of their units get shields. It's like playing against the protoss in Starcraft all over again.  Another thing is that defenses suck (unless you play with the old Tiberium Essence mod) - there's no walls and turrets are pretty weak.   All in all I'd give it a 7/10 because I loved the previous C&C games and EA did a good job of continuing the story for the Tiberium series, but it is lacking in some areas that could have been executed better.
Great game, even after years it's still a challenge and always entertaining :)

Now, if you're reading this, you love command and conquer. In my opinion, this is the bes of them, and as far as im concerned, the series died here, and died well. This game is a highly addictive RTS game that used the hints at alien existence in the previous games to create huge twist and add a lot more depth to the game. If you play as the GDI, you should focus on vehicle divisions, Nod focuses on infantry and stealth tactics as seen with their damned stealth tanks...and the Scrin...well...for your sake, I hope you have AA defenses...or you are doomed before you start...
